body:
@Kami Thank you for the driver. Any reason the driver uses a old version of the Cloudflare API -> https://www.cloudflare.com/docs/client-api.html .
CloudFlare is removing support for this API on November 9th, 2016.
@dol I think that when I added it, new version of the API wasn't there yet (or I missed it).

Ok. Sorry, the question was unfortunate.
Any plans switching over to the new API version?
I don't have any plans, but contributions are welcome (you can also ping / ask CloudFlare people).
I'm not that frequent in Python. Might be better to call your friends.
Small nit about allowing other param types, but otherwise LGTM!

I've merged PR into trunk and also made changes so failure on writing and reading token to / from file is not fatal - 2f02aecebc4ba371b1239378961675a477ab9086, 25c414e33526bb647f93db4f2adb8ad0120b4957.

I also added logging statement on failure, but we don't really have any common logging standards and practices established in Libcloud yet so that's something we need to improve in the future (among other things, we need to make sure that when `LIBCLOUD_DEBUG` is set that those messages are written to sys.stderr, etc.).

Thanks again!

Thanks for the contribution.

The change looks good to me.
Merged, thanks!
thanks luke. I'm not sure why the attributes need to be declared in both the driver and the connection class?

@tonybaloney I only see two changes. One within libcloud/common/azure.py and one within libcloud/common/base.py.

The change within libcloud/common/base.py retains the existing functionality(which breaks AzureBlobStorage) and allows overriding which is set in libcloud/common/azure.py.

Please can you clarify where you are seeing any additional changes.

thanks
Luke
thanks @marcaurele +1
thanks @The-Loeki have you tested this? I don't really understand the issue but wondered if the string should be "_" instead of "[]_"?

Hello,

Does anyone see any issues with this code?  Can someone review and merge if possible please.

thanks
Luke

@tonybaloney Thanks & we're running it in production already ;) 

As I mentioned, the same bug surfaced in CloudMonkey (CloudStack's own API-driven CLI tool), and the fix was the same.

All API calls are signed & verified based on, amongst others, the encoded URL. This must apparently exclude HTML-encoding asterisks or the sig is invalid (as will the entire req be).

Of course it doesn't happen very often that a \* is in the values, so that explains why this wasn't noticed for so long.
The `safe` param is just a list of exceptions pretending to be a `str`, so the order shouldnt make a difference (it's not a regex or anything)
ok, thats a strange bug. :+1:

thanks @JamieH, the tests are broken because of the way it checks for mock methods (that's simple to fix). But, I'm pretty sure in all my tests that I left a `/` at the end of my connection string.
Can you try that for me too? Maybe it makes more sense to check for the existence of it in `__init__`, because users may or may not put a / at the end of the host.
no, all good. üëç
thanks @lrvan for the contribution, I had a couple of questions (commented) about the method names and approach.
üëç thanks @foriegnbody

I'm having issues with the patch file. never happened before! @Kami  can you try and merge this one? 

```
error: patch failed: libcloud/common/base.py:532
error: libcloud/common/base.py: patch does not apply
error: Did you hand edit your patch?
It does not apply to blobs recorded in its index.
Patch failed at 0001 Fix for AzureBlobStorage not allowing upload with 400 error (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-842). The issue was created when a fix for "AWSRequestSignerAlgorithmV4" (https://github.com/apache/libcloud/commit/4bff0f076776e6d59945381c1e2969826131fc11) was added. This caused the heads "host" and "accept_encoding" to be removed from the requests to AzureBlobStorage. The Fix retains the current functionality and sets the headers on for Azure.
```
too easy üëç
I'm pushing this in unless any serious objections?
@tonybaloney  thanks for reviewing!

Apparently too easy :( I confused the API behavior with a CLI behavior.

Fixed in #852
Thanks @illfelder! Could you help improve testing a bit around images and cover this change? https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/test/compute/test_gce.py#L1177

I've played around with testing and spoken about it with @wrigri. It appears that existing tests for libcloud only verify that the correct API is called, not the body of the request. As a result, we can't find a supported way to verify that using "ACTION" translates to an empty request body. If you know of one, please let us know.
@tonybaloney I thought I did have an ICLA on file, but I didn't, so thanks for asking.  It's now on file with Apache.
That's cool @supertom, I don't have access to check them. I won't ask again!
Any chance of getting this merged? We're currently running a locally hacked libcloud version to get around this problem.
woah. Ok, please can you give me a little description over what is in this PR @famanson ?
üëç thanks @steve-gregory

nope, same merge issue. Did one of you force push a changeset or something? This is really strange. 

```
Applying: Fix for AzureBlobStorage not allowing upload with 400 error (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-842). The issue was created when a fix for "AWSRequestSignerAlgorithmV4" (https://github.com/apache/libcloud/commit/4bff0f076776e6d59945381c1e2969826131fc11) was added. This caused the heads "host" and "accept_encoding" to be removed from the requests to AzureBlobStorage. The Fix retains the current functionality and sets the headers on for Azure.
Using index info to reconstruct a base tree...
error: patch failed: libcloud/common/base.py:532
error: libcloud/common/base.py: patch does not apply
error: Did you hand edit your patch?
It does not apply to blobs recorded in its index.
Patch failed at 0001 Fix for AzureBlobStorage not allowing upload with 400 error (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-842). The issue was created when a fix for "AWSRequestSignerAlgorithmV4" (https://github.com/apache/libcloud/commit/4bff0f076776e6d59945381c1e2969826131fc11) was added. This caused the heads "host" and "accept_encoding" to be removed from the requests to AzureBlobStorage. The Fix retains the current functionality and sets the headers on for Azure.
The copy of the patch that failed is found in: .git/rebase-apply/patch
When you have resolved this problem, run "git am --continue".
If you prefer to skip this patch, run "git am --skip" instead.
To restore the original branch and stop patching, run "git am --abort".
```

also, convention is that optional parameters that are not defined in the base classes are prepending with `ex_` so I'd ask that the filter was `ex_network_id`. BUT, I'm assuming this is the Network Domain and not the MCP 1 network? In which case, `ex_network_domain_id`, just to make people type a few more characters.
@tonybaloney Updated based on your comments.  Please re-review.
@tonybaloney eh? This was supposed to be an internal PR into our fork... I think I'll close this PR and come back when this has been polished

@tonybaloney Hey, as you might be able to tell @famanson  and I are trying to build a driver for the newer API. We were wondering whether you know how we can contact the libcloud developers or anyone who would be willing to collaborate/help us push our work upstream? We currently have something that works specifically for our own uses, but is not a finished product to be merged.

That would be me (or anyone else that merges PRs). 
Do you have a list of outstanding changes?

@famanson you probably picked the wrong upstream, so you raised a PR against the actual apache/libcloud repository. It makes sense now why the patch doesn't work as your trunk is probably also out of sync with the apache/libcloud trunk. We'll need to get that aligned as well.
@tonybaloney yeah, github UI defaulted to libcloud upstream (I created the PR from there). We'll work on getting everything ready for a proper push

For a new set of features like this, I usually try to include working examples in `demos/gce_demo.py` also.  Doing that can serve (somewhat) as both documentation and a live integration test.

I typically run this script every time we make some change that has a risk of introducing a bug or breaking change.  While it doesn't come close to full test cases or code coverage, it's a small safety net.

Do you mind extending the script for to include this new work?

It's a good idea, and in fact, it's how I test my changes.  

The blocker/slowdown in doing it was not having  'create' support for InstanceTemplates or Unmanaged Instance Groups.  As these are features that are not used often (at least, I suspect that they aren't), I had put them off.  But, it's not too much effort so I think I will just add them in and then update the demo.

@tonybaloney We're basically a driver for the newer Azure API https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-gb/library/azure/dn790568.aspx. At the moment @famanson has built just enough so that the following functions work:
    - `list_locations`
    - `list_sizes`
    - `list_nodes`
    - `create_node`
The main differences between this at the existing Azure driver are the API calls and handling the json requests and responses. We would need help in finishing the other functions and also deploying Windows VMs, because currently the code only allows Linux VMs to be deployed.

I would like to get involved with this integration I have done the 
following:
- list_nodes
- list_sizes
- list_images
- ex_start_node
- ex_stop_node
- reboot_node
- destroy_node

In addition I use the proper Azure SDK instead of direct rest calls 
which I believe is a bit more maintainable and readable, snippet:

https://bpaste.net/show/cc6df02c43b7

Let me know your thoughts and what the steps moving forward should be.

The error from https://travis-ci.org/apache/libcloud/jobs/160522709 seems to be a flaky installation error whereas the error from https://travis-ci.org/apache/libcloud/jobs/160522727:

```
pylint runtests: commands[0] | pylint -E --rcfile=./.pylintrc libcloud/common/
************* Module libcloud.common.dimensiondata
E:489,18: Instance of 'unicode' has no 'get' member (no-member)
E:490,20: Instance of 'unicode' has no 'get' member (no-member)
E:491,39: Instance of 'unicode' has no 'get' member (no-member)
```

Appears to be a pylint error. The variable being referred to is an Element, not a unicode, object:

```
-> yield paged_resp
(Pdb) paged_resp
<Element '{urn:didata.com:api:cloud:types}servers' at 0x1100a7a90>
```

Compare the last commit's build with the build I ran against my fork and notice that only the pylint error shows up: https://travis-ci.org/relaxdiego/libcloud/builds/160750260

yep this doesn't work either.

@lmorfitt OK I've figured it out by just cloning your fork and reading back through the log, so basically the commit ref that you created this after is part of a change that you didn't include in this. We apply patches using `git am` because all Apache git repo's are not hosted by GitHub, they are actually clones. Anyway. I'm assuming you don't want the Azure ARM driver that's in the git history of your trunk to be included in the PR and just the individual driver connection setting changes?

looks simple enough to me. Is `Windows` really a feature? :-P
@crunk1 can you explain the motivations behind the PR please?
LGTM. thanks for your contribution

Google Cloud Storage doesn't have a method exposed to query for, or set, permissions on containers or objects. This PR adds the functionality to do so. Internally at Google, I have built some libraries on top of libcloud and I need a way to get and set permissions on GCS entities.
IntEnum was a helper class that I made for my changes, but I purposefully made it more generalized and put it in common/types.py with the idea to share it.
Thanks, creating and attaching patch to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-852
@illfelder

The IntEnum addition looks like it could be generically useful across more of the code base. I'm pretty sure I've used dicts and sorted key lists for things like this. But I wonder if it would be better to decouple this and introduce IntEnum more broadly (across more of libcloud) to help us all move to this model?  My concern with keeping it joined with the GCS changes, we'd all forget about it and the generic solution would not get adopted elsewhere at which point, this becomes a more complex solution than needed purely for the GCS changes.

wdyt?

Nice @InAnimaTe 

Random comments related to the Rancher integration...
- A little late now, but we do have a python [API binding](https://github.com/rancher/gdapi-python) you could use.
- Listing every field of resources like container/service is going to quickly be out of date..    I don't know if passing a map is an option that fits into the rest of libcloud rather than 30 positional params, but if so you can save a lot of work keeping it in sync.
- resource.transitioning == 'yes' would be better for PENDING state than endswith('ing')  
- API `v2[-beta]` renames `environment` to `stack`, so while you might not want to use v2 yet (for compatibility with Rancher v1.1.x) you should probably refer to it as a stack in the public interface.
- `outputs`, `previousEnvironment` & `previousExternalId` are technically settable by users for obscure technical reasons, but are not _really_ user inputs.  So you could remove those as options for a env/stack.
I agree, having all those arguments is outrageous and will fail quickly. No reason why the common ones can't be called out directly and the rest of them just accepted as `kwargs`.

:+1: I agree something needs to be updated with the SSL settings for newer versions of Python.

Might want to consider how 2.7.13 and 3.5.3 just changed the way SSL settings are applied (see [`ssl.PROTOCOL_TLS`](https://docs.python.org/2/library/ssl.html#ssl.PROTOCOL_TLS)) due to OpenSSL deprecating version specific protocols.
I think it is a little beyond the scope of this PR, but I agree with your opinion. Could I put it in a subsequent PR?
Yes please! I think teasing that out separately and doing something more basic for GCS now would be easier.
PTAL, IntEnum logic and other cleanup removed from this PR.
